title: Why many flight attendants actually prefer working in Economy to Business Class
text:
SKY HIGH DEMANDS Why many flight attendants actually prefer working in Economy to Business Class 
The demands of 10 rich people can often be more exhausting than serving 100 regular passengers By Caroline McGuire, Digital Travel Editor 21st February 2017, 12:36 pm Comments Everyone wants to be upgraded on a flight, apart from the flight attendants it seems. 
You’d think the cabin crew would much prefer working for a handful of posh people in Business or First Class, instead of hundreds of flustered passengers in Economy, but it turns out that’s not the case. Getty Images 3 Many flight attendants actually prefer working in Economy to Business Class as the passengers are less demanding (file photo) 
Many airlines have an promotion system, where you start off in economy, then work your way up to business and first class, but other companies let the crew choose where they want to work for that flight. 
Because according to the accounts of several flight attendants, while they might be serving 10 people instead of 70 in the fancy cabins, their constant demands actually mean they work a lot harder. 
Heather Wilde, a former cabin crew member said that the work is far more straightforward in Economy. RELATED STORIES Plane Facts Flight attendants reveal 10 things passengers don’t know… including service is best at the back of the plane 'WE KNOW YOU'RE J***ING OFF' Flight attendants want you to stop doing these things on their aeroplanes MILE-HIGH MANNERS 10 things you should never say to a flight attendant... from 'fetch me a drink' to 'watch my kids' MID-AIR MELTDOWN Dramatic moment brawl breaks out after 'passenger punches female flight attendant' during flight to London sparking emergency landing 'That isn't water you're feeling' Flight attendants reveal why you should NEVER take your shoes off on a plane 
She said on Quora : “When flying economy, everything was straightforward – the most senior flight attendant on the plane would handle all the announcements, paperwork and stocking, in addition to everyone’s duties of completing the drink/snack service, aisle checks, etc. 
“In a First Class experience there was no time to rest as you have to be able to cater to every passenger every minute of the flight – and ensure you still make all the required announcements at the right times. 
“It honestly made me feel like a sky waitress.” Getty Images 3 While flight attendants might be serving 10 people instead of 70 in the fancy cabins, their constant demands actually mean they work a lot harder (file photo) 
Nuralia Mazlan added: “Serving 100 people in economy class is better than 16 in business class anytime for me. 
“Passengers take their meal and don’t complain much, then we do collection for their rubbish and they’re done. Dim the cabin lights and get ready to sleep.” 
According to various crew members, the routes the plane is operating on can dictate quite how push the business or first class passengers might be. 
For instance, one Reddit user called Emmadilemma said: “I normally love working as the First Class flight attendant, except for LA flights. 
“Everyone on the plane to LAX airport is a princess and deserves to be treated like a celebrity – in their own minds.” Getty Images 3 According to one flight attendant, most of the time Economy passengers take their meal and don’t complain much, then go to sleep (file photo) 
For other airlines, Business Class passengers are the rudest when travelling between New York and London, or New York to Miami. 
A flight attendant called Brad told The Independent : “[On an] NYC-Florida flight, everyone thinks they’re the most important person in the world. 
“I once had a forty-something male passenger who said he was a picky eater and asked me to remove the almonds from his mixed nuts, the shaved Parmesan from his salad and the cilantro from his tabouleh.”
